column4: ok - if I copy a bunch of *.deb packages from one computer to another - how can I get them to be recognized by apt?
I can't download them all again - this is a dial-up connection
you don't, not easily anyway
well...
there has got to be a way to do this. .
i can only think of setting up a local mirror
well you can certainly install them one by one
perhaps i would just write a script to do that, i guess it would be easier than setting up a mirror
would dpkg manage the dependencies?
try writing a script like this, "for Package in /directory/containing/packages/*; do dpkg -i "$Package"; done"
no, it wouldn't. indeed, i was just going to tell you that this script should be run *many times*, until all the dependencies have been solved ;)
not the cleanest method i could come up with, i guess, but i think it will work
sounds horrible. . .   how hard would it be to set up a local mirror?
I'll google it - nevermind
yeah, you should google it, i don't really know. have a look at the "apt-move" package though
apt-proxy too, though that's intended as - you guess - a proxy. but perhaps you could fool it into accepting the packages you already have =)
but really, i guess apt-move will do most of the work - that is create the directory hierarchy for a mirror. at that point, you can just install an HTTP or FTP server and use it in your sources.list
I can probably just set up a local mirror from my laptop. . I've got an ftp server setup already. . shouldn't be too bad
postgres: actual SQL support :-) MySQL: more widespread
the faster one i meant mysql.
myself, i'd use postgres all day. but it's best to make up your own mind
the reason I ask is because I've been trying to cross-compile MySQL for the past 2 days from linux to windows. . it's damn near impossible
